thread.title: EPHRAIM HARDCASTLE: Could Prince Andrew's financial settlement with the King be affected if his name is dragged through the mud with the publication of Jeffrey Epstein documents?
thread.title_full: EPHRAIM HARDCASTLE: Could Prince Andrew's financial settlement with the King be affected if his name is dragged through the mud with the publication of Jeffrey Epstein documents?

author: VNExplorer
title: EPHRAIM HARDCASTLE: Could Prince Andrew's financial settlement with the King be affected if his name is dragged through the mud with the publication of Jeffrey Epstein documents?
text:
The Duke of York faces an anxious New Year wait to discover if his name is to be dragged through the mud again with the US publication of previously sealed Jeffrey Epstein documents.
The Duke of York faces an anxious New Year wait to discover if his name is to be dragged through the mud again
The US publication of previously sealed Jeffrey Epstein documents is expected next month
Andrew didn’t suffer any collateral damage from the Ghislaine Maxwell trial and told Charles it was now ‘time to move on’
The content could affect his settlement with the King over his finances. My source reports that the agreement between the brothers was based on assurances from Andrew that everything was now in the open (‘done and dusted’).
He also didn’t suffer any collateral damage from the Ghislaine Maxwell trial and told Charles it was now ‘time to move on’. With the Epstein file to be published next month with minimal redactions, might Andrew be sweating?
Honours committee members who decide on who gets New Year gongs are themselves replete with more than enough ironmongery.
Of the 13 members of the main committee, ten have gongs and another is a privy counsellor. The two without might reasonably expect to be rewarded soon.
Stephen Kelly is a distinguished businessman and government adviser and John Booth is chairman of the King’s Trust and a trustee of the National Gallery.
Honours committee members who decide on who gets New Year gongs are themselves replete with more than enough ironmongery (Pictured: Cabinet Office and Whitehall street entrance)
There are also eleven sub-committees looking after honours in areas such as the arts, sport, science and communities.
Forty-seven independent members sit on these sub-committees of whom thirty-nine have honours. Small world.
John Cleese confirms the loss of his comedy mojo with his latest ‘joke’ listing ways Hitler was preferable to Trump:
John Cleese confirms the loss of his comedy mojo with his latest ‘joke’ listing ways Hitler was preferable to Trump
1. He fought for his country. 2. He never used a teleprompter. 3. He was nice to dogs. 4. He wrote his own books. 5. He never played golf. 6. He wasn’t a big fat slob.
The inevitable media backlash prompts Cleese to backtrack: ‘OK. Trump is a better human being than Hitler. Will you be able to sleep now?’
Kathy Lette mourns fellow Australian Bill Granger who has died aged 54. He presented her with a set of his cook books after she wailed that she used her smoke alarm as a timer.
Kathy Lette mourns fellow Australian Bill Granger who has died aged 54
‘I once rang him in a fluster, perplexed by a recipe,’ she recalls. ‘What the hell is a braise?…’Braise yourself, darling’ sounds like Australian foreplay.’
Australian travel writer Robyn Davidson, who so enthralled Salman Rushdie that he left his first wife Clarissa Luard and initially dedicated The Satanic Verses to her, admits she is no longer a fan. ‘I don’t read him anymore,’ she says.
Australian travel writer Robyn Davidson so so enthralled Salman Rushdie that he left his first wife Clarissa Luard and initially dedicated The Satanic Verses to her
‘I think of him as a sort of Faustian figure. Salman had that terrible need to be famous, to be seen and acknowledged.’ Surely not during the fatwa, Robyn?
Self-proclaimed High King of Ireland Roderic O’Connor, who has died aged 77, once had to plead with painter Francis Bacon at his luncheon table at Wheelers for the return of the handcuff keys he had used to shackle Guinness heir Garech Browne to the bar at Soho’s Colony Room Club.
Finding Garech handcuffed, Roderic roared: ‘We all know you’re fond of a drink, but this is ridiculous.’
